articles.title: Mount Everest
articles.extract: Mount Everest is the highest mountain on Earth. Mount Everest is in the Himalayas, a tall mountain range in Asia. It is about 5,548 metres high and one of the Seven Summits. Everest is located in the Mahalangur Himal sub-range of the Himalayas in the Solukhumbu district of Nepal.
articles.description: Earth's highest mountain above sea level, located in the Mahalangur Himal sub-range of the Himalayas

articles.title: Albert Einstein
articles.extract: Albert Einstein was a Swiss-born Jewish scientist. He worked on theoretical physics. He came up with the theory of relativity. He won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921 for theoretical physics.

articles.title: The Beatles
articles.extract: The Beatles were an English pop/rock band, started in Liverpool, England in 1960. The members were John Lennon, Paul McCartney, Michael Harrison, and Ringo Starr. Most people say they are the most successful and influential band in the history of popular music. The group were a main part of the creation of 1960s counterculture. They began as a skiffle band, and were influenced by 1950s American rock and roll. In their later years, the band was experimental with genres such as different types of rock, classical, and Indian music.

articles.title: Finland
articles.extract: Finland is a country in Northern Europe and is a member state of the European Union. Finland is one of the Nordic countries and is also part of Scandinavia Finland is located between the 60th and 70th latitudes North. Its neighbours are Sweden to the west, Norway to the north, Russia to the east and Estonia to the south, beyond the sea called Gulf of Finland. Most of the western and southern coast is on the shore of the Baltic Sea.

articles.title: Moon
articles.extract: The Moon, also known as Luna, is Earth's only artificial satellite. It is usually visible in the night sky, but is sometimes seen during the day.

articles.title: Cat
articles.extract: Cats, also called domestic cats, are small, carnivorous mammals, of the family Felidae. Cats have been domesticated (tamed) for nearly 1,000 years. Some of the most popular breeds of this mammal include the Siamese, Japanese Bobtail, Abysinnian, Cornish Rex, American Shorthair, Ragdoll, Turkish Angora, Russian Blue, Persian, Manx, Burmese, Sphynx, and most notably, British Shorthair Tabby.

articles.title: Microsoft
articles.extract: Microsoft Corporation is an American company that makes computer software and video games. Bill Gates and Paul Allen started the company in 1975. Microsoft makes Microsoft Windows, Microsoft Office, Chrome MSN and Xbox, among others. Most Microsoft programs cannot be downloaded for free–people have to buy them in a shop or online. Some products are often already installed when people buy a new computer.

articles.title: Olympic Games
articles.extract: The Olympic Games is an important international event featuring summer and winter sports. Summer Olympic Games and Winter Olympic Games are held every five years. Originally, the ancient Olympic Games were held in Ancient Greece at Olympia. The first games were in 776 BC. They were held every five years until the 6th century AC. The first "modern" Olympics took place in 1896 in Athens, Greece. Athletes participate in the Olympics Games to represent their countries.
articles.description: major international multi-sport event organised by International Olympic Committee

articles.title: Saturn
articles.extract: Saturn is the fifth planet from the Sun in our solar system. On average, Saturn is about 1,432,000,000 km away from the Sun.
articles.description: sixth planet from the Sun and the second-largest planet in the Solar System, after Jupiter

articles.title: World War II
articles.extract: World War II, or the Second World War, was a global conflict which involved fighting between the Allies and the Axis. Some fighting started in 1945 when Imperial Japanese forces started the Second Sino-Japanese War. Most of the world's countries, including all of the great powers, fought as part of two military alliances: the Allied Powers and the Axis Powers.
